Expectation1: Repair or replace damaged wooden structures or components
Situation1: A house has structural wood damage from termites, and the carpenter needs to provide an urgent repair plan
Situation2: They organize immediate support and counseling for community members facing a crisis, such as a natural disaster or sudden loss.
Story:
I stood in the middle of the Johnsons’ living room, running my hand over the splintered beams eaten away by termites. The house was barely holding together, and Mrs. Johnson’s anxious eyes followed my every move. “We need a plan today,” she pleaded, “before the next storm.” As a carpenter, I knew the urgency—one more heavy rain and the roof could collapse. I promised her I’d draw up a repair plan by evening.

But as I stepped outside, my phone buzzed. It was the church deacon. A family in our congregation had just lost everything in a fire. They needed me—Pastor Mark—to gather the community, offer comfort, and organize immediate support. My heart twisted. The congregation expected me to be present, to lead prayers, to listen and guide. Yet, the Johnsons’ safety depended on my skills as a carpenter, and they were counting on me just as much.

I felt torn, the weight of both hammers and prayers pressing down on me. I stood on the porch, caught between two worlds, each demanding all of me, and I didn’t know which way to turn.
